text: Jesus said to His disciples, “It is inevitable that stumbling blocks will come, but woe to the person through whom they come!
It would be better for that person to have a millstone hung around their neck and be thrown into the sea than to cause one of these little ones to sin.
Be on your guard! If your brother or sister sins against you, rebuke them; and if they repent, forgive them.
Even if they sin against you seven times in a day and come back to you seven times saying, ‘I repent,’ you must forgive them.”
The apostles implored the Lord, “Strengthen our faith!”
The Lord replied, “If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be uprooted and planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you.
“Suppose one of you has a servant ploughing or tending sheep. Would you say to the servant when he comes in from the field, ‘Come now and sit down to eat’?
Would you not rather say, ‘Prepare my supper, get yourself ready and serve me while I eat and drink; after that you may eat and drink’?
Would you thank the servant because he did what he was commanded to do?
So you also, when you have completed all that was instructed, should say, ‘We are humble servants; we have only fulfilled our responsibility.’”
While Jesus was on His way to Jerusalem, He travelled along the border between Samaria and Galilee.
As He was entering a village, ten men with leprosy met Him. They stood at a distance
and called out in a loud voice, “Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!”
When He noticed them, He instructed, “Go, show yourselves to the priests.” And as they went, they were cleansed.
One of them, upon realizing he was healed, returned, glorifying God in a loud voice.
He fell at Jesus’ feet and expressed his gratitude—and he was a Samaritan.
Jesus inquired, “Were all ten not cleansed? Where are the other nine?
Is there no one here to honour God except this outsider?”
Then He told him, “Stand up and continue on your way; your faith has restored you.”
Once, being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, Jesus replied, “The arrival of the kingdom of God is not something that can be observed,
nor will people say, ‘Here it is,’ or ‘There it is,’ because the kingdom of God is among you.”
Then He said to His disciples, “The days are coming when you will long to see one of the days of the Son of Man, but you will not see it.
People will say to you, ‘Look, there he is!’ or ‘Here he is!’ Do not go running off after them.
For the Son of Man in His day will be like lightning, which flashes and illuminates the sky from one end to the other.
But first He must endure many things and be rejected by this generation.
Just as it was during the time of Noah, so it will be in the days of the Son of Man.
People were eating, drinking, marrying, and being given in marriage until the day Noah entered the ark. Then the flood came and destroyed them all.
It was similar in the days of Lot. People were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting and building.
Yet, on the day Lot departed from Sodom, fire and sulphur descended from heaven and destroyed them all.
In the same way, it will be when the Son of Man is revealed.
On that day no one on the housetop, with possessions inside, should go down to get them. Likewise, no one in the field should go back for anything.
Do not forget the lesson of Lot’s wife!
Whoever seeks to preserve their life will lose it, and whoever loses their life will keep it.
I tell you, on that night two people will be in one bed; one will be taken and the other left behind.
Two women will be grinding grain together; one of them will be taken and the other will be left behind.
[Two men will be in the field; one will be taken and the other left.”]
“Where, Lord?” they asked. He replied, “Where there is a body, there the vultures will gather.”
